ProcedureHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: PROC GCHART <DATA=input-data-set> 
      <ANNOTATE=Annotate-data-set> 
      <GOUT=<libref.>output-catalog> 
      <IMAGEMAP=output-data-set>;  
      BLOCK chart-variable(s) </ option(s)>;  
      HBAR | HBAR3D | VBAR | VBAR3D chart-variable(s) </ option(s)>;  
      PIE | PIE3D | DONUT chart-variable(s) </ option(s)>;  
      STAR chart-variable(s) </ option(s)>;  

The GCHART procedure produces six types of charts: block charts, horizontal and vertical bar 
charts, pie and donut charts, and star charts. These charts graphically represent the value of 
a statistic calculated for one or more variables in an input SAS data set. The charted variables 
can be either numeric or character.

The procedure calculates these statistics: 
  o frequency or cumulative frequency counts 
  o percentages or cumulative percentages 
  o sums 
  o means

Use the GCHART procedure to do the following tasks:
  o display and compare exact and relative magnitudes 
  o examine the contribution of parts to the whole 
  o analyze where data are out of balance

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ANNOTATE=Annotate-data-set] 
      
Specifies a data set to annotate all graphs that are produced by the GCHART procedure. 
To annotate individual graphs, use ANNOTATE= in the action statement.

[Syntax: DATA=input-data-set] 
      
Specifies the SAS data set that contains the variable or variables to chart. By default, 
the procedure uses the most recently created SAS data set.

[Syntax: GOUT=<libref.>output-catalog] 
      
Specifies the SAS catalog in which to save the graphics output that is produced by the GCHART 
procedure. If you omit the libref, SAS/GRAPH looks for the catalog in the temporary library called 
WORK and creates the catalog if it does not exist.

[Syntax: IMAGEMAP=output-data-set] 
      
Creates a temporary SAS data set that is used to generate an image map in an HTML output file. 
The information in the image map data set includes the shape and coordinates of the elements in 
the graph and drill-down URLs that have been associated with those elements. The drill-down URLs 
are provided by one or two variables in the input data set. These variables are identified to the 
GCHART procedure with the HTML= or HTML_LEGEND= or both options.

The %IMAGEMAP macro generates the image map in the HTML output file. The macro takes two arguments, 
the name of the image map data set and the name or fileref of the HTML file, as shown in the following 
example: 

  %imagemap(imgmapds, myimgmap.html);
  
Restriction: Not supported by Java or ActiveX

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BLOCK chart-variable(s) </ option(s)>;
      
The BLOCK statement specifies the variable or variables that define the categories of data 
to chart. This statement automatically does the following actions:

  o determines the midpoints 
  o calculates the chart statistic for each midpoint (the default is FREQ) 
  o scales the blocks according to the statistic value 
  o assigns patterns and colors to the block faces and the grid; the default block pattern is solid

You can use statement options to select or order the midpoints (blocks), to change the type 
of chart statistic, and to modify the appearance of the chart. You can also specify additional 
variables by which to group, subgroup, or sum the data.

Block charts enable grouping, which organizes the blocks into rows based on the values of a 
group variable, and subgrouping, which subdivides the blocks into segments based on the values 
of a subgroup variable.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ANNOTATE=Annotate-data-set] 
          
Specifies a data set to annotate charts produced by the BLOCK statement.

[Syntax: BLOCKMAX=max-value] 
          
Specifies the chart statistic value of the tallest block on the chart. This option lets you 
produce a series of block charts using the same scale.

[Syntax: CAXIS=grid-color] 
          
Specifies the color for the midpoint grid.

[Syntax: COUTLINE=block-outline-color | SAME] 
          
Outlines all blocks or all block segments and legend values in the subgroup legend 
(if it appears) using the specified color. SAME specifies that the outline color of 
a block or a block segment or a legend value is the same as the interior pattern color.

[Syntax: COUTLINE=block-outline-color | SAME] 
          
Outlines all blocks or all block segments and legend values in the subgroup legend 
(if it appears) using the specified color. SAME specifies that the outline color of 
a block or a block segment or a legend value is the same as the interior pattern color.

[Syntax: CTEXT=text-color] 
          
Specifies a color for all text on the axes and legend, including axis labels, tick mark 
values, legend labels, and legend value descriptions.

[Syntax: DESCRIPTION='description'] 
          
Specifies the description of the catalog entry for the chart. The maximum length for 
entry-description is 256 characters. The description does not appear on the chart. By 
default, the GCHART procedure assigns a description of the form BLOCK CHART OF variable, 
where variable is the name of the chart variable.

The entry-description can include the #BYLINE, #BYVAL, and #BYVAR substitution options, 
which work as they do when used on TITLE, FOOTNOTE, and NOTE statements.

Treats a numeric chart variable as a discrete variable rather than as a continuous variable. 
The GCHART procedure creates a separate midpoint and, hence, a separate grid square and block 
for each unique value of the chart variable.

[Syntax: FREQ=numeric-variable] 
          
Specifies a variable whose values weight the contribution of each observation in the computation 
of the chart statistic. Each observation is counted the number of times specified by the value of 
numeric-variable for that observation. If the value of numeric-variable is missing, 0, or negative, 
the observation is not used in the statistic calculation. Non-integer values of numeric-variable are 
truncated to integers.

FREQ= is valid with all chart statistics.

Because you cannot use the PERCENT, CPERCENT, FREQ, or CFREQ statistics with the SUMVAR= option, 
you must use the FREQ= option to calculate percentages, cumulative percentages, frequencies, or 
cumulative frequencies based on a sum.

The statistics are not affected by applying a format to numeric-variable.

[Syntax: GAXIS=AXIS<1...99>] 
          
Assigns the specified AXIS definition to the group axis. (A group axis is created when you use 
the GROUP= option.) You can use the AXIS definition to modify the order of the groups, the text 
of the labels, and appearance of the axis. GAXIS= is ignored if the specified AXIS definition 
does not exist.

Calculates the percentage and cumulative percentage statistics separately for each group. 
When you use G100, the individual percentages reflect the contribution of the midpoint to 
the group and total 100 percent for each group. G100 is ignored unless you also use the 
GROUP= option.

By default, the individual percentages reflect the contribution of the midpoint to the entire 
chart and total 100 percent for the entire chart.

[Syntax: GROUP=group-variable] 
          
Organizes the data according to the values of group-variable. Group-variable can be either 
character or numeric and is always treated as a discrete variable. The group variable can 
have up to 12 different values.

[Syntax: HTML=variable] 
          
Identifies the variable in the input data set whose values create links in the HTML file that 
is created by the ODS statement. These links are associated with an area of the chart and point 
to the data or graph you want to display when the user drills down on the area. There is no limit 
on the length of the variable.

[Syntax: HTML_LEGEND=variable] 
          
Identifies the variable in the input data set whose values create links in the HTML file that 
is created by the ODS statement. These links are associated with an area of the chart and point 
to the data or graph you want to display when the user drills down on the area. There is no limit 
on the length of the variable.

[Syntax: LEGEND=LEGEND<1...99>] 
          
Assigns the specified LEGEND definition to the legend generated by the SUBGROUP= option. 
The LEGEND= option itself does not generate a legend.

[Syntax: LEVELS=number-of-midpoints] 
          
Specifies the number of midpoints for the numeric chart variable.

[Syntax: MAXIS=AXIS<1...99>] 
          
Assigns the specified AXIS definition to the midpoint axis. The MAXIS= option is ignored 
if the specified AXIS definition does not exist.

The Java and ActiveX devices do not support all AXIS statement options.

[Syntax: MIDPOINTS=value-list | OLD] 
          
Specifies the midpoint values for the blocks. The way you specify value-list depends on the 
type of variable:
          
For numeric chart variables, value-list is either an explicit list of values, or a starting 
and an ending value with an interval increment, or a combination of both forms: 

     n <...n>
     
     n TO n <BY increment>
     
     n<...n> TO n <BY increment> <n <...n>>
 
For character chart variables, value-list is a list of unique character values enclosed in 
quotation marks and separated by blanks: 

    'value-1' <...'value-n'> 
    
MIDPOINTS=OLD generates default midpoints using the Nelder algorithm.
Generates default midpoints using the Nelder algorithm.

Accepts a missing value as a valid midpoint for the chart variable. By default, observations 
with missing values are ignored.

[Syntax: NAME='entry-name'] 
          
Specifies the name of the GRSEG catalog entry and the name of the graphics output file, 
if one is created.
Suppresses the legend generated by the LEGEND= option.
Specifies the way fill patterns are assigned.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Changes patterns each time the value of the BY variable changes. All bars use the same pattern  if the GBARLINE procedure does not include a BY statement.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Changes patterns every time the midpoint value changes.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Changes patterns every time the value of the subgroup variable changes.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: RAXIS=value-list | AXIS<1...99>] 
          
Specifies values for the major tick mark divisions on the response axis or assigns 
the specified AXIS definition to the axis.

[Syntax: SUBGROUP=subgroup-variable] 
          
Divides the blocks into segments according to the values of subgroup-variable. Subgroup-variable 
can be either character or numeric and is always treated as a discrete variable.

[Syntax: SUMVAR=summary-variable] 
          
Specifies a numeric variable for sum or mean calculations. The GCHART procedure calculates the 
sum or, if requested, the mean of numeric-variable for each midpoint. The resulting statistics 
are represented by the height of the blocks in each square. The values of a summary variable  
used with the BLOCK statement have a maximum length of 8.

When you use SUMVAR=, the TYPE= option value must be either SUM or MEAN. With SUMVAR=, the 
default is TYPE=SUM.
Specifies the chart statistic.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: [Valid if the SUMVAR= opion is not used]--Frequency
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: [Valid if the SUMVAR= opion is not used]--Cumulative frequency
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: [Valid if the SUMVAR= opion is not used]--Percentage
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: [Valid if the SUMVAR= opion is not used]--Cumulative percentage
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: [Valid if the SUMVAR= opion is used]--Sum
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: [Valid if the SUMVAR= opion is used]--Mean

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[URL=character-variable 
          
Specifies a character variable whose values are URLs. The variable values are URLs for 
Web pages to display when the user clicks (drills down) on elements in the graph. 

Restrictions: This option affects graphics output that is created through the ODS HTML 
destination only. Not supported by GIF, PNG, and ACTIVEX devices.

Interaction: If you specify both the HTML= and the URL= options, then the URL= option 
is ignored.

[Syntax: WOUTLINE=block-outline-width] 
          
Specifies the width of the block outline in pixels.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: HBAR chart-variable*width-variable SUMVAR=numeric-variable</ option(s)>; 
      
The HBAR, HBAR3D, VBAR, and VBAR3D statements specify the variable or variables that define 
the categories of data to chart. These statements automatically do the following:

  o determine the midpoints 
  o calculate the chart statistic for each midpoint (the default is FREQ) 
  o scale the response axis and the bars according to the statistic value 
  o determine bar width and spacing 
  o assign patterns to the bars; the default bar/block pattern is SOLID 
  o draw a frame around the axis area using a color determined by the current style, or, 
    if the NOGSTYLE option is specified, using the first color in the device's color list

You can use statement options to select or order the midpoints (bars), to control the tick marks 
on the response axis, to change the type of chart statistic, to display specific statistics, and 
to modify the appearance of the chart. You can also specify additional variables by which to group, 
subgroup, or sum the data.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ANNOTATE=Annotate-data-set] 
          
Specifies a data set to annotate charts produced by the BAR statement.
Arranges the bars in ascending order of the value of the bar statistic.
Draws a reference line at each major tick mark on the bar (left) response axis.

[Syntax: AXIS=AXIS<1...99>] 
          
Specifies values for the major tick mark divisions on the response axis or assigns the 
specified AXIS definition to the axis.

[Syntax: CAUTOREF=reference-line-color] 
          
Specifies the color of reference lines drawn at major tick marks, as determined by the 
AUTOREF option.

[Syntax: CAXIS=axis-color] 
          
Specifies a color for the response and midpoint axis lines and for the default axis area frame.

[Syntax: CERROR=error-bar-color] 
          
Specifies the color of error bars. The default color is the color of the response axis, 
which is controlled by the CAXIS= option.

[Syntax: CFRAME=background-color] 
          
Specifies the color with which to fill the axis area in two-dimensional bar charts or in 
the backplane in three-dimensional bar charts.
Displays the cumulative frequency statistic above vertical bars.

[Syntax: CFREQLABEL='column-label' | NONE] 
          
Specifies the text of the column label for the CFREQ statistic in the table of statistics. 
Column-label can be up to 32 characters long, but a single line of the label can be no more 
than 24 characters.
Clips the reference lines at the bars. This makes the reference lines appear to be behind the bars.

[Syntax: CLM=confidence-level] 
          
Specifies the confidence intervals to use when drawing error bars. Values for confidence-level 
must be greater than or equal to 50 and strictly less than 100. The default is 95.

[Syntax: COUTLINE=bar-outline-color | SAME] 
          
Outlines all bars or bar segments and legend values in the subgroup legend (if it appears) 
using the specified color. SAME specifies that the outline color of a bar or a bar segment 
or a legend value is the same as the interior pattern color.
[Displays the cumulative percentage statistic above the vertical bars.

[Syntax: CREF=reference-line-color|(reference-line-color)|reference-line-color-list] 
          
Specifies colors for reference lines.

[Syntax: CPERCENTLABEL='column-label' | NONE] 
          
Specifies the text of the column label for the CPERCENT statistic in the table of statistics. 
Column-label can be up to 32 characters long, but a single line of the label can be no more 
than 24 characters. To suppress the label, specify CPERCENTLABEL=NONE.

[Syntax: CTEXT=text-color] 
          
Specifies a color for all text on the axes and legend, including axis labels, tick mark values, 
legend labels, and legend value descriptions.
Arranges the bars in descending order of the value of the chart statistic.

[Syntax: DESCRIPTION='entry-description'] 
          
Specifies the description of the catalog entry for the chart. The maximum length for the 
entry-description is 256 characters.
Treats a numeric chart variable as a discrete variable rather than as a continuous variable.

Draws confidence intervals for either of the following:

o the mean of the SUMVAR= variable for each midpoint if you specify TYPE=MEAN

o the percentage of observations assigned to each midpoint if you specify TYPE=PCT with no SUMVAR= option.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Draws error bars as bars half the width of the main bars.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Draws error bars as two ticks joined by a line (default).
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Draws the error bar as a tick for the upper confidence limit that is joined to the top of  the bar by a line.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies that the two-dimensional axis area frame or the three-dimensional backplane is drawn.
Specifies that two-dimensional axis area frame or the three-dimensional backplane is not drawn.
Displays the frequency statistic in the table of statistics and above vertical bars.

[Syntax: FREQLABEL='column-label' | NONE] 
          
Specifies the text of the column label for the FREQ statistic in the table of statistics. 
column-label can be up to 32 characters long, but a single line of the label can be no more 
than 24 characters.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Replace <'column-label'> with the column label for FREQ statistic in the table of statistics.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies no column label for the FREQ statistic in the table of statistics.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: FREQ=numeric-variable] 
          
Specifies a variable whose values weight the contribution of each observation in the 
computation of the chart statistic.
Calculates the percentage and cumulative percentage statistics separately for each group.

[Syntax: GAXIS=AXIS<1...99>] 
          
Assigns the specified AXIS definition to the group axis. (A group axis is created when you 
use the GROUP= option.)

[Syntax: GROUP=group-variable] 
          
Organizes the data according to values of group-variable. Group-variable can be either 
character or numeric and is always treated as a discrete variable.

[Syntax: GSPACE=group-spacing] 
          
Specifies the amount of extra space between groups of bars. Group-space can be any 
non-negative number. Units are character cells.

[Syntax: HTML=variable] 
          
Identifies the variable in the input data set whose values create links in the HTML file 
created by the ODS statement.

[Syntax: HTML_LEGEND=variable] 
          
Identifies the variable in the input data set whose values create links in the HTML file 
that is created by the ODS statement.

[Syntax: IFRAME=fileref | 'external-file'] 
          
Specifies an image file to use on a 2-D chart's frame area or a 3-D chart's backplane.

Specifies whether to use multiple instances of an image to fill the axis frame or backplane (TILE) 
or to stretch a single instance of an image to fill the axis frame or backplane frame (FIT). The 
TILE value is the default.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to use multiple instances of an image to fill the axis frame or backplane.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to stretch a single instance of an image to fill the axis frame or backplane frame.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Displays the values of the specified statistic inside the bars.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Frequencies
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Cumulative frequencies. [Note: Not valid if the bars are subgrouped.]
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Cumulative percentages. [Note: Not valid if the bars are subgrouped.]
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Means. [Note: Not valid if the bars are subgrouped.]

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: LAUTOREF=reference-line-type] 
          
Specifies the line type for reference lines at major tick marks, as determined by the AUTOREF option.

[Syntax: LEGEND=LEGEND<1...99>] 
          
Assigns the specified LEGEND definition to the legend generated by the SUBGROUP= option.

[Syntax: LEVELS=number-of-midpoints | ALL] 
          
Specifies the number of midpoints for the numeric chart variable. The range for each midpoint 
is calculated automatically, using the algorithm in Terrell and Scott (1985).

If you specify LEVELS=ALL, then all unique midpoint values are graphed. If your data contains 
a large number of unique midpoint values (over 200), you can use the XPIXELS and YPIXELS GOPTIONS 
to enable the device driver to render a larger (and more readable) graph.

The LEVELS= option is ignored if any of the following are true:

  o The chart variable is character type. 
  o The DISCRETE option is used. 
  o The MIDPOINTS= option is used.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Replace <number-of-midpoints> with the desired number of midpoints for the numeric chart variable.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that all unique midpoint values are graphed. If your data contains a large number  of unique midpoint values (over 200), you can use the XPIXELS and YPIXELS GOPTIONS to enable  the device driver to render a larger (and more readable) graph.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: LREF=reference-line-type|( reference-line-type|reference-line-type-list)] 
          
Specifies line types for reference lines. Line types are specified as whole numbers from 1 to 46, 
with 1 representing a solid line and the other values representing dashed lines.

[Syntax: MAXIS=AXIS<1...99] 
          
Assigns the specified AXIS definition to the midpoint axis.
Displays the mean statistic in the table of statistics and above vertical bars.

[Syntax: MEANLABEL='column-label' | NONE] 
          
Specifies the text of the column label for the MEAN statistic in the table of statistics. 
column-label can be up to 32 characters long, but a single line of the label can be no more 
than 24 characters.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Replace <'column-label'> with the column label for the MEAN statistic in the table of statistics.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies no column label for the MEAN statistic in the table of statistics.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: MIDPOINTS=value-list | OLD] 
          
Specifies the midpoint values for the bars. The way you specify value-list depends on the 
type of the chart variable.
          
For numeric chart variables, value-list is either an explicit list of values, or a starting 
and an ending value with an interval increment, or a combination of both forms: 

     n <...n>
     
     n TO n <BY increment>
     
     n<...n> TO n <BY increment> <n <...n>>
 
For character chart variables, value-list is a list of unique character values enclosed in 
quotation marks and separated by blanks: 

    'value-1' <...'value-n'> 
    
MIDPOINTS=OLD generates default midpoints using the Nelder algorithm.

Generates default midpoints using the Nelder algorithm. The MIDPOINTS=OLD option is ignored 
unless the chart variable is numeric.

[Syntax: MINOR=number-of-minor-ticks] 
          
Specifies the number of minor tick marks between each major tick mark on the bar response axis.

Accepts a missing value as a valid midpoint for the chart variable. By default, observations 
with missing values are ignored.

[Syntax: NAME='entry-name'] 
          
Specifies the name of the GRSEG catalog entry and the name of the graphics output file, 
if one is created.

Suppresses all axes, including axis lines, axis labels, axis values, and all major and 
minor tick marks.
Suppresses the zero reference line when the SUM or MEAN bar statistic has negative values.
Suppresses the legend that is automatically generated by the SUBGROUP= option.

Removes either the horizontal or vertical three-dimensional axis plane in bar charts produced 
by the HBAR3D and VBAR3D statements.

Suppresses the table of statistics. The NOSTATS option suppresses both the default statistics and 
specific statistics requested by the FREQ, CFREQ, PERCENT, CPERCENT, SUM, and MEAN options.

Suppresses any midpoints for which there are no corresponding values of the chart variable and, 
hence, no bar.
Displays the values of the specified statistic above the bars.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Frequencies
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Cumulative frequencies
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Cumulative percentages

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the way fill patterns are assigned.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Changes patterns each time the value of the BY variable changes. All bars use the same pattern if the GBARLINE procedure does not include a BY statement.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Changes patterns every time the midpoint value changes.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Changes patterns every time the value of the subgroup variable changes.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Prints the percentages of observations having a given value for the chart variable in the table 
of statistics and above vertical bars.
calculates a percent of the sum variable for horizontal bar charts.

[Syntax: PERCENTLABEL='column-label' | NONE] 
          
Specifies the text of the column label for the PERCENT statistic in the table of statistics. 
column-label can be up to 32 characters long, but a single line of the label can be no more 
than 24 characters.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Replace <'column-label'> with the column label for the PERCENT statistic in the table of statistics.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies no column label for the PERCENT statistic in the table of statistics.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Displays on the axis of the chart the range of numeric values represented by each bar.

[Syntax: RAXIS=value-list | AXIS<1...99>] 
          
Specifies values for the major tick mark divisions on the response axis or assigns the 
specified AXIS definition to the axis.

[Syntax: REF=value-list] 
          
Draws reference lines at the specified points on the chart response axis.

[Syntax: SPACE=bar-spacing] 
          
Specifies the amount of space between individual bars or between the bars within each group 
if you also use the GROUP= option.

[Syntax: SUBGROUP=subgroup-variable] 
          
Divides the bars into segments according to the values of subgroup-variable. Subgroup-variable 
can be either character or numeric and is always treated as a discrete variable.
Displays the sum statistic in the table of statistics and above vertical bars.

[Syntax: SUMLABEL='column-label' | NONE] 
          
Specifies the text of the column label for the SUM statistic in the table of statistics. 
column-label can be up to 32 characters long, but a single line of the label can be no more 
than 24 characters.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Replace <'column-label'> with the column label for the SUM statistic in the table of statistics.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies no column label for the SUM statistic in the table of statistics.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: SUMVAR=summary-variable] 
          
Specifies a numeric variable for sum or mean calculations.
Specifies the chart statistic.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: [Valid if the SUMVAR= option is not used]--Frequency
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: [Valid if the SUMVAR= option is not used]--Cumulative frequency
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: [Valid if the SUMVAR= option is not used]--Percentage
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: [Valid if the SUMVAR= option is not used]--Cumulative percentage
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: [Valid if the SUMVAR= option is used]--Sum
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: [Valid if the SUMVAR= option is used]--Mean

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[URL=character-variable 
          
Specifies a character variable whose values are URLs. The variable values are URLs for 
Web pages to display when the user clicks (drills down) on elements in the graph. 

Restrictions: This option affects graphics output that is created through the ODS HTML 
destination only. Not supported by GIF, PNG, and ACTIVEX devices.

Interaction: If you specify both the HTML= and the URL= options, then the URL= option 
is ignored.

[Syntax: WAUTOREF=reference-line-width] 
          
Specifies the line width for reference lines at major tick marks, as determined by the AUTOREF option.

[Syntax: WIDTH=bar-width] 
          
Specifies the width of the bars. By default, the GCHART procedure selects a bar width that 
accommodates the midpoint values displayed on the midpoint axis using a hardware font and a 
height of one cell. Units for bar-width are character cells. The value for bar-width must be 
greater than 0, but it does not have to be an integer, for example: 

  vbar site / width=1.5;
  
If the requested bar width results in a chart that is too large to fit in the space available 
for the midpoint axis, then the procedure issues a warning in the log and ignores the WIDTH= 
option. If the specified width is too narrow, the procedure displays the midpoint values vertically.

[Syntax: WOUTLINE=bar-outline-width] 
          
Specifies the width of the outline in pixels. The WOUTLINE= option affects both the bar 
and the subgroup outlines.

[Syntax: WREF=reference-line-width|( reference-line-width|reference-line-width-list)] 
          
Specifies line widths for reference lines. Line widths are specified as whole numbers. 
To specify colors for these reference lines, use the CREF= option.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: HBAR3D chart-variable*width-variable SUMVAR=numeric-variable</ option(s)>; 
      
The HBAR, HBAR3D, VBAR, and VBAR3D statements specify the variable or variables that define 
the categories of data to chart. These statements automatically do the following:

  o determine the midpoints 
  o calculate the chart statistic for each midpoint (the default is FREQ) 
  o scale the response axis and the bars according to the statistic value 
  o determine bar width and spacing 
  o assign patterns to the bars; the default bar/block pattern is SOLID 
  o draw a frame around the axis area using a color determined by the current style, or, 
    if the NOGSTYLE option is specified, using the first color in the device's color list

You can use statement options to select or order the midpoints (bars), to control the tick marks 
on the response axis, to change the type of chart statistic, to display specific statistics, and 
to modify the appearance of the chart. You can also specify additional variables by which to group, 
subgroup, or sum the data.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ANNOTATE=Annotate-data-set] 
          
Specifies a data set to annotate charts produced by the BAR statement.
Arranges the bars in ascending order of the value of the bar statistic.
Draws a reference line at each major tick mark on the bar (left) response axis.

[Syntax: AXIS=AXIS<1...99>]

[Syntax: LEVELS=number-of-midpoints | ALL] 
          
Specifies the number of midpoints for the numeric chart variable. The range for each midpoint 
is calculated automatically, using the algorithm in Terrell and Scott (1985).

If you specify LEVELS=ALL, then all unique midpoint values are graphed. If your data contains 
a large number of unique midpoint values (over 200), you can use the XPIXELS and YPIXELS GOPTIONS 
to enable the device driver to render a larger (and more readable) graph.

The LEVELS= option is ignored if any of the following are true:

  o The chart variable is character type. 
  o The DISCRETE option is used. 
  o The MIDPOINTS= option is used.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[URL=character-variable 
          
Specifies a character variable whose values are URLs. The variable values are URLs for 
Web pages to display when the user clicks (drills down) on elements in the graph. 

Restrictions: This option affects graphics output that is created through the ODS HTML 
destination only. Not supported by GIF, PNG, and ACTIVEX devices.

Interaction: If you specify both the HTML= and the URL= options, then the URL= option 
is ignored.

[Syntax: WAUTOREF=reference-line-width] 
          
Specifies the line width for reference lines at major tick marks, as determined by 
the AUTOREF option.

[Syntax: WIDTH=bar-width] 
          
Specifies the width of the bars. By default, the GCHART procedure selects a bar width that 
accommodates the midpoint values displayed on the midpoint axis using a hardware font and a 
height of one cell. Units for bar-width are character cells. The value for bar-width must be 
greater than 0, but it does not have to be an integer, for example: 

  vbar site / width=1.5;
  
If the requested bar width results in a chart that is too large to fit in the space available 
for the midpoint axis, then the procedure issues a warning in the log and ignores the WIDTH= 
option. If the specified width is too narrow, the procedure displays the midpoint values 
vertically.

[Syntax: WOUTLINE=bar-outline-width] 
          
Specifies the width of the outline in pixels. The WOUTLINE= option affects both the bar 
and the subgroup outlines.

[Syntax: WREF=reference-line-width|( reference-line-width|reference-line-width-list)] 
          
Specifies line widths for reference lines. Line widths are specified as whole numbers. 
To specify colors for these reference lines, use the CREF= option.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: VBAR chart-variable*width-variable SUMVAR=numeric-variable</ option(s)>; 
      
The HBAR, HBAR3D, VBAR, and VBAR3D statements specify the variable or variables that define 
the categories of data to chart. These statements automatically do the following:

  o determine the midpoints 
  o calculate the chart statistic for each midpoint (the default is FREQ) 
  o scale the response axis and the bars according to the statistic value 
  o determine bar width and spacing 
  o assign patterns to the bars; the default bar/block pattern is SOLID 
  o draw a frame around the axis area using a color determined by the current style, or, 
    if the NOGSTYLE option is specified, using the first color in the device's color list

You can use statement options to select or order the midpoints (bars), to control the tick marks 
on the response axis, to change the type of chart statistic, to display specific statistics, and 
to modify the appearance of the chart. You can also specify additional variables by which to group, 
subgroup, or sum the data.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[URL=character-variable 
          
Specifies a character variable whose values are URLs. The variable values are URLs for 
Web pages to display when the user clicks (drills down) on elements in the graph. 

Restrictions: This option affects graphics output that is created through the ODS HTML 
destination only. Not supported by GIF, PNG, and ACTIVEX devices.

Interaction: If you specify both the HTML= and the URL= options, then the URL= option 
is ignored.

[Syntax: WAUTOREF=reference-line-width] 
          
Specifies the line width for reference lines at major tick marks, as determined by the AUTOREF option.

[Syntax: WIDTH=bar-width] 
          
Specifies the width of the bars. By default, the GCHART procedure selects a bar width that 
accommodates the midpoint values displayed on the midpoint axis using a hardware font and a 
height of one cell. Units for bar-width are character cells. The value for bar-width must be 
greater than 0, but it does not have to be an integer, for example: 

  vbar site / width=1.5;
  
If the requested bar width results in a chart that is too large to fit in the space available 
for the midpoint axis, then the procedure issues a warning in the log and ignores the WIDTH= 
option. If the specified width is too narrow, the procedure displays the midpoint values vertically.

[Syntax: WOUTLINE=bar-outline-width] 
          
Specifies the width of the outline in pixels. The WOUTLINE= option affects both the bar 
and the subgroup outlines.

[Syntax: WREF=reference-line-width|( reference-line-width|reference-line-width-list)] 
          
Specifies line widths for reference lines. Line widths are specified as whole numbers. 
To specify colors for these reference lines, use the CREF= option.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: VBAR3D chart-variable*width-variable SUMVAR=numeric-variable</ option(s)>; 
      
The HBAR, HBAR3D, VBAR, and VBAR3D statements specify the variable or variables that define 
the categories of data to chart. These statements automatically do the following:

  o determine the midpoints 
  o calculate the chart statistic for each midpoint (the default is FREQ) 
  o scale the response axis and the bars according to the statistic value 
  o determine bar width and spacing 
  o assign patterns to the bars; the default bar/block pattern is SOLID 
  o draw a frame around the axis area using a color determined by the current style, or, 
    if the NOGSTYLE option is specified, using the first color in the device's color list

You can use statement options to select or order the midpoints (bars), to control the tick marks 
on the response axis, to change the type of chart statistic, to display specific statistics, and 
to modify the appearance of the chart. You can also specify additional variables by which to group, 
subgroup, or sum the data.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ANNOTATE=Annotate-data-set] 
          
Specifies a data set to annotate charts produced by the BAR statement.
Arranges the bars in ascending order of the value of the bar statistic.
Draws a reference line at each major tick mark on the bar (left) response axis.

[Syntax: AXIS=AXIS<1...99>] 
          
Specifies values for the major tick mark divisions on the response axis or assigns the 
specified AXIS definition to the axis.

[Syntax: CAUTOREF=reference-line-color] 
          
Specifies the color of reference lines drawn at major tick marks, as determined by the 
AUTOREF option.

[Syntax: CAXIS=axis-color] 
          
Specifies a color for the response and midpoint axis lines and for the default axis area frame.

[Syntax: CERROR=error-bar-color] 
          
Specifies the color of error bars. The default color is the color of the response axis, 
which is controlled by the CAXIS= option.

[Syntax: CFRAME=background-color] 
          
Specifies the color with which to fill the axis area in two-dimensional bar charts or in 
the backplane in three-dimensional bar charts.
Displays the cumulative frequency statistic above vertical bars.

[Syntax: CFREQLABEL='column-label' | NONE] 
          
Specifies the text of the column label for the CFREQ statistic in the table of statistics. 
Column-label can be up to 32 characters long, but a single line of the label can be no more 
than 24 characters.

Clips the reference lines at the bars. This makes the reference lines appear to be 
behind the bars.

[Syntax: CLM=confidence-level] 
          
Specifies the confidence intervals to use when drawing error bars. Values for confidence-level 
must be greater than or equal to 50 and strictly less than 100. The default is 95.

[Syntax: COUTLINE=bar-outline-color | SAME] 
          
Outlines all bars or bar segments and legend values in the subgroup legend (if it appears) 
using the specified color. SAME specifies that the outline color of a bar or a bar segment 
or a legend value is the same as the interior pattern color.
[Displays the cumulative percentage statistic above the vertical bars.

[Syntax: CREF=reference-line-color|(reference-line-color)|reference-line-color-list] 
          
Specifies colors for reference lines.

[Syntax: CPERCENTLABEL='column-label' | NONE] 
          
Specifies the text of the column label for the CPERCENT statistic in the table of statistics. 
Column-label can be up to 32 characters long, but a single line of the label can be no more 
than 24 characters. To suppress the label, specify CPERCENTLABEL=NONE.

[Syntax: CTEXT=text-color] 
          
Specifies a color for all text on the axes and legend, including axis labels, tick mark values, 
legend labels, and legend value descriptions.
Arranges the bars in descending order of the value of the chart statistic.

[Syntax: DESCRIPTION='entry-description'] 
          
Specifies the description of the catalog entry for the chart. The maximum length for the 
entry-description is 256 characters.
Treats a numeric chart variable as a discrete variable rather than as a continuous variable.

Draws confidence intervals for either of the following:

o the mean of the SUMVAR= variable for each midpoint if you specify TYPE=MEAN

o the percentage of observations assigned to each midpoint if you specify TYPE=PCT with no SUMVAR= option.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Draws error bars as bars half the width of the main bars.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Draws error bars as two ticks joined by a line (default).
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Draws the error bar as a tick for the upper confidence limit that is joined to the top of  the bar by a line.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies that the two-dimensional axis area frame or the three-dimensional backplane is drawn.
Specifies that two-dimensional axis area frame or the three-dimensional backplane is not drawn.
Displays the frequency statistic in the table of statistics and above vertical bars.

[Syntax: FREQLABEL='column-label' | NONE] 
          
Specifies the text of the column label for the FREQ statistic in the table of statistics. 
column-label can be up to 32 characters long, but a single line of the label can be no more 
than 24 characters.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Replace <'column-label'> with the column label for FREQ statistic in the  table of statistics.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies no column label for the FREQ statistic in the table of statistics.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: FREQ=numeric-variable] 
          
Specifies a variable whose values weight the contribution of each observation in the 
computation of the chart statistic.
Calculates the percentage and cumulative percentage statistics separately for each group.

[Syntax: GAXIS=AXIS<1...99>] 
          
Assigns the specified AXIS definition to the group axis. (A group axis is created when you 
use the GROUP= option.)

[Syntax: GROUP=group-variable] 
          
Organizes the data according to values of group-variable. Group-variable can be either 
character or numeric and is always treated as a discrete variable.

[Syntax: GSPACE=group-spacing] 
          
Specifies the amount of extra space between groups of bars. Group-space can be any 
non-negative number. Units are character cells.

[Syntax: HTML=variable] 
          
Identifies the variable in the input data set whose values create links in the HTML file 
created by the ODS statement.

[Syntax: HTML_LEGEND=variable] 
          
Identifies the variable in the input data set whose values create links in the HTML file 
that is created by the ODS statement.

[Syntax: IFRAME=fileref | 'external-file'] 
          
Specifies an image file to use on a 2-D chart's frame area or a 3-D chart's backplane.

Specifies whether to use multiple instances of an image to fill the axis frame or backplane (TILE) 
or to stretch a single instance of an image to fill the axis frame or backplane frame (FIT). The 
TILE value is the default.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies to use multiple instances of an image to fill the axis frame or backplane.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to stretch a single instance of an image to fill the axis frame or backplane frame.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Displays the values of the specified statistic inside the bars.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Frequencies
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Cumulative frequencies. [Note: Not valid if the bars are subgrouped.]
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Cumulative percentages. [Note: Not valid if the bars are subgrouped.]
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Means. [Note: Not valid if the bars are subgrouped.]

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: LAUTOREF=reference-line-type] 
          
Specifies the line type for reference lines at major tick marks, as determined by 
the AUTOREF option.

[Syntax: LEGEND=LEGEND<1...99>] 
          
Assigns the specified LEGEND definition to the legend generated by the SUBGROUP= option.

[Syntax: LEVELS=number-of-midpoints | ALL] 
          
Specifies the number of midpoints for the numeric chart variable. The range for each midpoint 
is calculated automatically, using the algorithm in Terrell and Scott (1985).

If you specify LEVELS=ALL, then all unique midpoint values are graphed. If your data contains 
a large number of unique midpoint values (over 200), you can use the XPIXELS and YPIXELS GOPTIONS 
to enable the device driver to render a larger (and more readable) graph.

The LEVELS= option is ignored if any of the following are true:

  o The chart variable is character type. 
  o The DISCRETE option is used. 
  o The MIDPOINTS= option is used.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Replace <number-of-midpoints> with the desired number of midpoints for the numeric chart variable.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that all unique midpoint values are graphed. If your data contains a large number  of unique midpoint values (over 200), you can use the XPIXELS and YPIXELS GOPTIONS to enable  the device driver to render a larger (and more readable) graph.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: LREF=reference-line-type|( reference-line-type|reference-line-type-list)] 
          
Specifies line types for reference lines. Line types are specified as whole numbers from 1 to 46, 
with 1 representing a solid line and the other values representing dashed lines.

[Syntax: MAXIS=AXIS<1...99] 
          
Assigns the specified AXIS definition to the midpoint axis.
Displays the mean statistic in the table of statistics and above vertical bars.

[Syntax: MEANLABEL='column-label' | NONE] 
          
Specifies the text of the column label for the MEAN statistic in the table of statistics. 
column-label can be up to 32 characters long, but a single line of the label can be no more 
than 24 characters.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Replace <'column-label'> with the column label for the MEAN statistic in the  table of statistics.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies no column label for the MEAN statistic in the table of statistics.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: MIDPOINTS=value-list | OLD] 
          
Specifies the midpoint values for the bars. The way you specify value-list depends on the 
type of the chart variable.
          
For numeric chart variables, value-list is either an explicit list of values, or a starting 
and an ending value with an interval increment, or a combination of both forms: 

     n <...n>
     
     n TO n <BY increment>
     
     n<...n> TO n <BY increment> <n <...n>>
 
For character chart variables, value-list is a list of unique character values enclosed in 
quotation marks and separated by blanks: 

    'value-1' <...'value-n'> 
    
MIDPOINTS=OLD generates default midpoints using the Nelder algorithm.

Generates default midpoints using the Nelder algorithm. The MIDPOINTS=OLD option is ignored 
unless the chart variable is numeric.

[Syntax: MINOR=number-of-minor-ticks] 
          
Specifies the number of minor tick marks between each major tick mark on the bar response axis.

Accepts a missing value as a valid midpoint for the chart variable. By default, 
observations with missing values are ignored.

[Syntax: NAME='entry-name'] 
          
Specifies the name of the GRSEG catalog entry and the name of the graphics output file, 
if one is created.

Suppresses all axes, including axis lines, axis labels, axis values, and all major 
and minor tick marks.
Suppresses the zero reference line when the SUM or MEAN bar statistic has negative values.
Suppresses the legend that is automatically generated by the SUBGROUP= option.

Removes either the horizontal or vertical three-dimensional axis plane in bar charts produced 
by the HBAR3D and VBAR3D statements.

Suppresses the table of statistics. The NOSTATS option suppresses both the default statistics and 
specific statistics requested by the FREQ, CFREQ, PERCENT, CPERCENT, SUM, and MEAN options.

Suppresses any midpoints for which there are no corresponding values of the chart variable and, 
hence, no bar.
Displays the values of the specified statistic above the bars.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Frequencies
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Cumulative frequencies
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Cumulative percentages

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the way fill patterns are assigned.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Changes patterns each time the value of the BY variable changes. All bars use the  same pattern if the GBARLINE procedure does not include a BY statement.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Changes patterns every time the midpoint value changes.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Changes patterns every time the value of the subgroup variable changes.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Prints the percentages of observations having a given value for the chart variable in the table 
of statistics and above vertical bars.
calculates a percent of the sum variable for horizontal bar charts.

[Syntax: PERCENTLABEL='column-label' | NONE] 
          
Specifies the text of the column label for the PERCENT statistic in the table of statistics. 
column-label can be up to 32 characters long, but a single line of the label can be no more 
than 24 characters.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Replace <'column-label'> with the column label for the PERCENT statistic in the table of statistics.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies no column label for the PERCENT statistic in the table of statistics.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Displays on the axis of the chart the range of numeric values represented by each bar.

[Syntax: RAXIS=value-list | AXIS<1...99>] 
          
Specifies values for the major tick mark divisions on the response axis or assigns the 
specified AXIS definition to the axis.

[Syntax: REF=value-list] 
          
Draws reference lines at the specified points on the chart response axis.

[Syntax: SPACE=bar-spacing] 
          
Specifies the amount of space between individual bars or between the bars within each group 
if you also use the GROUP= option.

[Syntax: SUBGROUP=subgroup-variable] 
          
Divides the bars into segments according to the values of subgroup-variable. Subgroup-variable 
can be either character or numeric and is always treated as a discrete variable.
Displays the sum statistic in the table of statistics and above vertical bars.

[Syntax: SUMLABEL='column-label' | NONE] 
          
Specifies the text of the column label for the SUM statistic in the table of statistics. 
column-label can be up to 32 characters long, but a single line of the label can be no more 
than 24 characters.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Replace <'column-label'> with the column label for the SUM statistic in the table of statistics.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies no column label for the SUM statistic in the table of statistics.

Specifies a numeric variable for sum or mean calculations.
Specifies the chart statistic.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: [Valid if the SUMVAR= option is not used]--Cumulative frequency

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[URL=character-variable 
          
Specifies a character variable whose values are URLs. The variable values are URLs for 
Web pages to display when the user clicks (drills down) on elements in the graph. 

Restrictions: This option affects graphics output that is created through the ODS HTML 
destination only. Not supported by GIF, PNG, and ACTIVEX devices.

Interaction: If you specify both the HTML= and the URL= options, then the URL= option 
is ignored.

[Syntax: WAUTOREF=reference-line-width] 
          
Specifies the line width for reference lines at major tick marks, as determined by the AUTOREF option.

[Syntax: WIDTH=bar-width] 
          
Specifies the width of the bars. By default, the GCHART procedure selects a bar width that 
accommodates the midpoint values displayed on the midpoint axis using a hardware font and a 
height of one cell. Units for bar-width are character cells. The value for bar-width must be 
greater than 0, but it does not have to be an integer, for example: 

  vbar site / width=1.5;
  
If the requested bar width results in a chart that is too large to fit in the space available 
for the midpoint axis, then the procedure issues a warning in the log and ignores the WIDTH= 
option. If the specified width is too narrow, the procedure displays the midpoint values 
vertically.

[Syntax: WOUTLINE=bar-outline-width] 
          
Specifies the width of the outline in pixels. The WOUTLINE= option affects both the bar 
and the subgroup outlines.

[Syntax: WREF=reference-line-width|( reference-line-width|reference-line-width-list)] 
          
Specifies line widths for reference lines. Line widths are specified as whole numbers. 
To specify colors for these reference lines, use the CREF= option.

[Syntax: ACROSS=number-of-columns] 
          
Draws number-of-columns pies across the procedure output area. ACROSS is ignored unless 
you also use the GROUP= option.

[Syntax: ANGLE=degrees] 
          
Starts the first slice at the specified angle. A value of 0 for degrees corresponds to the 
three o'clock position.

[Syntax: ANNOTATE=Annotate-data-set] 
          
Specifies a data set to annotate charts produced by the PIE, PIE3D, or DONUT statement. 

Note: Annotate coordinate systems 1, 2, 7, and 8 (data system coordinates) are not valid 
with pie or donut charts.
Arranges the slices in ascending order of the value of the chart statistic.

[Syntax: CFILL=fill-color] 
          
Specifies one color for all patterns in the chart, regardless of whether the fill 
is solid or hatch.
Draws the slices clockwise starting at the twelve o'clock position.

[Syntax: COUTLINE=slice-outline-color | SAME] 
          
Outlines all slices, rings (subgroups), and legend values (if a legend appears) in the 
specified color. SAME specifies that the outline color of a slice or a slice segment or 
a legend value is the same as the interior pattern color.

[Syntax: COUTLINE=slice-outline-color | SAME] 
          
Outlines all slices, rings (subgroups), and legend values (if a legend appears) in the 
specified color. SAME specifies that the outline color of a slice or a slice segment or 
a legend value is the same as the interior pattern color.

[Syntax: CTEXT=text-color] 
          
Specifies a color for all text on the axes and legend, including axis labels, tick mark 
values, legend labels, and legend value descriptions.
Arranges the slices in descending order of the value of the chart statistic.

[Syntax: DESCRIPTION='description'] 
          
Specifies the description of the catalog entry for the chart. The maximum length 
for entry-description is 256 characters.

[Syntax: DETAIL=variable] 
          
Produces an inner pie overlay whose slices show the major components that comprise the 
outer pie's slice.

[Syntax: DETAIL_PERCENT=BEST|NONE] 
          
Specifies the algorithm to use for displaying the percentage values for the detail pie slices. 
NONE turns off the display of the percentage values.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the BEST algorithm for displaying the percentage values for the detail pie slices.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Turns off the display of the percentage values.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: DETAIL_RADIUS=percent] 
          
Determines the size of the detail pie. Percent specifies the percent of the outer pie 
radius to use as the detail pie radius. The valid range is 25 to 90. The default is 75.

[Syntax: DETAIL_SLICE=BEST|NONE] 
          
Specifies the algorithm to use for displaying the detail variable labels for the inner 
pie slices. NONE turns off the display of the detail variable labels.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the BEST algorithm for displaying the detail variable labels for the inner pie slices.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Turns off the display of the detail variable labels.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: DETAIL_THRESHOLD=percent] 
          
Determines whether a detail slice is included in the inner pie. Any detail slice comprising percent 
or more percent of the whole pie is included. The valid range for percent is 0 to 75. The default is 4.

[Syntax: DETAIL_VALUE=BEST|NONE] 
          
Specifies the algorithm to use for displaying the data values for the detail pie slices. 
NONE turns off the display of the data values.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the BEST algorithm for displaying the data values for the detail pie slices.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Turns off the display of the data values.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Treats a numeric chart variable as a discrete variable rather than as a continuous variable. 
The GCHART procedure creates a separate midpoint and, hence, a separate grid square and block 
for each unique value of the chart variable.

[Syntax: DOWN=number-of-rows] 
          
Draws number-of-rows pies vertically in the procedure output area. The DOWN= option 
is ignored unless you also use the GROUP= option.

If number-of-rows calls for more pies than fit vertically in the graphics area of the 
output device, no pies are drawn and an error message is written to the SAS log.

If you also use the ACROSS= option, the pies are drawn in left-to-right and top-to-bottom order.

[Syntax: EXPLODE=value-list] 
          
Pulls the specified slices slightly out from the rest of the pie for added emphasis. 
value-list is the list of midpoint values for the slices to be exploded.
Specifies the fill pattern for all slices in the chart.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Rotates a solid fill through the color list of the current style as many times as necessary.  SOLID is the default.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Rotates a single hatch pattern through the list of colors defined in the current style.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: FREQ=numeric-variable] 
          
Specifies a variable whose values weight the contribution of each observation in the 
computation of the chart statistic.

[Syntax: GROUP=group-variable] 
          
Organizes the data according to the values of group-variable and produces a separate 
pie(or donut) chart for each unique value of group-variable. Group-variable can be either 
character or numeric and is always treated as a discrete variable. The group variable can 
have up to 12 different values.

[Syntax: HTML=variable] 
          
Identifies the variable in the input data set whose values create links in the HTML file 
that is created by the ODS statement. These links are associated with an area of the chart 
and point to the data or graph that you want to display when the user drills down on the area.

[Syntax: HTML_LEGEND=variable] 
          
Identifies the variable in the input data set whose values create links in the HTML file 
that is created by the ODS statement. These links are associated with a legend value and 
point to the data or graph that you want to display when the user drills down on the value. 
The values of variable can be up to 1024 characters long. Characters after the 1024-character 
limit (including any closing quotes) are truncated. If either subgroups or the DETAIL= option 
are specified, then the HTML_LEGEND= option is ignored.

[Syntax: INVISIBLE=value-list] 
          
Makes the specified slices invisible, as if they had been removed from the pie. Labels 
are not printed for invisible slices. Value-list is the list of midpoint values for the 
invisible slices.

Arranges the midpoints in descending order of the statistic value and draws the slices clockwise 
starting at the twelve o'clock position.

[Syntax: LEGEND=LEGEND<1...99>] 
          
Generates a legend for the slice names (midpoint values) instead of printing them beside the slices.

[Syntax: LEVELS=number-of-midpoints|ALL] 
          
Specifies the number of midpoints for a numeric chart variable. The range for each midpoint 
is calculated automatically.

If you specify LEVELS=ALL, then all unique midpoint values are graphed.

The LEVELS= option is ignored if any of the following is true:

  o The chart variable is character type.
  o The MIDPOINTS= option is used.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Replace <number-of-midpoints> with the desired number of midpoints for a numeric chart variable.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that all unique midpoint values are graphed. If your data contains a large number  of unique midpoint values (over 200), you can use the XPIXELS and YPIXELS GOPTIONS to enable  the device driver to render a larger (and more readable) graph.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Uses the slice pattern color for all slice labels. MATCHCOLOR overrides the color that 
is specified in the CTEXT= option.

[Syntax: MIDPOINTS=value-list | OLD] 
          
Specifies the midpoint values for the slices. The way you specify value-list depends on the 
type of variable:
          
For numeric chart variables, value-list is either an explicit list of values, or a starting 
and an ending value with an interval increment, or a combination of both forms: 

     n <...n>
     
     n TO n <BY increment>
     
     n<...n> TO n <BY increment> <n <...n>>
 
For character chart variables, value-list is a list of unique character values enclosed in 
quotation marks and separated by blanks: 

    'value-1' <...'value-n'> 
    
MIDPOINTS=OLD generates default midpoints using the Nelder algorithm.
Generates default midpoints using the Nelder algorithm.

Accepts a missing value as a valid midpoint for the chart variable. By default, observations 
with missing values are ignored.

[Syntax: NAME='entry-name'] 
          
Specifies the name of the GRSEG catalog entry and the name of the graphics output file, 
if one is created.
Suppresses the headings that are normally printed above each pie when you use the GROUP= option.

Suppresses the heading that is normally printed at the top of each page or display of output 
for all devices except Java and ActiveX.
Suppresses the legend that is automatically generated by the SUBGROUP= option

[Syntax: OTHER=percent-of-total] 
          
Collects all midpoints with chart statistic values less than or equal to percent-of-total 
into a generic midpoint named OTHER.

[Syntax: OTHERCOLOR=color] 
          
Specifies the color to use for the OTHER slice.

[Syntax: OTHERLABEL='text-string'] 
          
Specifies a text string up to 16 characters for the label for the OTHER slice. The default 
label is OTHER.
Prints the percentage represented by each slice using the specified labeling method.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Places the text outside the slice and connects the text to the slice with a line.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Places the text inside the slice. The label overlays the slice fill patterns.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Places the text outside of the slice.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: PLABEL=(text argument(s))] 
          
Defines the text that is displayed on the pie slice label. Text-argument(s) defines the text 
or the appearance of the label, or both.

[Syntax: RADIUS=value] 
          
Specifies the radius of the pie and donut in GCHART. RADIUS=n, where n is the pie radius in 
character cells.
Controls the position and style of the slice name (midpoint value) for each slice.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Places the text outside the slice and connects the text to the slice with a line.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Places the text inside the slice. The label overlays the slice fill patterns.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Places the text outside of the slice.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: SUBGROUP=subgroup-variable] 
          
Divides the chart into concentric rings according to the values of subgroup-variable. 
Subgroup-variable can be either character or numeric and is always treated as a discrete 
variable.

[Syntax: SUMVAR=summary-variable]

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:

Specifies the width of the block outline in pixels. WOUTLINE= affects both the slice 
and the subgroup outlines.

[Syntax: ACROSS=number-of-columns] 
          
Draws number-of-columns pies across the procedure output area. ACROSS is ignored unless 
you also use the GROUP= option.

[Syntax: ANGLE=degrees] 
          
Starts the first slice at the specified angle. A value of 0 for degrees corresponds to the 
three o'clock position.

[Syntax: ANNOTATE=Annotate-data-set] 
          
Specifies a data set to annotate charts produced by the PIE, PIE3D, or DONUT statement. 

Note: Annotate coordinate systems 1, 2, 7, and 8 (data system coordinates) are not valid 
with pie or donut charts.
Arranges the slices in ascending order of the value of the chart statistic.

[Syntax: CFILL=fill-color] 
          
Specifies one color for all patterns in the chart, regardless of whether the fill 
is solid or hatch.
Draws the slices clockwise starting at the twelve o'clock position.

[Syntax: COUTLINE=slice-outline-color | SAME] 
          
Outlines all slices, rings (subgroups), and legend values (if a legend appears) in the 
specified color. SAME specifies that the outline color of a slice or a slice segment or 
a legend value is the same as the interior pattern color.

[Syntax: COUTLINE=slice-outline-color | SAME] 
          
Outlines all slices, rings (subgroups), and legend values (if a legend appears) in the 
specified color. SAME specifies that the outline color of a slice or a slice segment or 
a legend value is the same as the interior pattern color.

[Syntax: CTEXT=text-color] 
          
Specifies a color for all text on the axes and legend, including axis labels, tick mark 
values, legend labels, and legend value descriptions.
Arranges the slices in descending order of the value of the chart statistic.

[Syntax: DESCRIPTION='description'] 
          
Specifies the description of the catalog entry for the chart. The maximum length 
for entry-description is 256 characters.

[Syntax: DETAIL_PERCENT=BEST|NONE] 
          
Specifies the algorithm to use for displaying the percentage values for the detail pie slices. 
NONE turns off the display of the percentage values.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the BEST algorithm for displaying the percentage values for the detail pie slices.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Turns off the display of the percentage values.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: DETAIL_RADIUS=percent] 
          
Determines the size of the detail pie. Percent specifies the percent of the outer 
pie radius to use as the detail pie radius. The valid range is 25 to 90. The default 
is 75.

[Syntax: DETAIL_SLICE=BEST|NONE] 
          
Specifies the algorithm to use for displaying the detail variable labels for the inner pie slices. 
NONE turns off the display of the detail variable labels.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the BEST algorithm for displaying the detail variable labels for the inner pie slices.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Turns off the display of the detail variable labels.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Turns off the display of the data values.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Treats a numeric chart variable as a discrete variable rather than as a continuous variable. 
The GCHART procedure creates a separate midpoint and, hence, a separate grid square and block 
for each unique value of the chart variable.

[Syntax: DOWN=number-of-rows] 
          
Draws number-of-rows pies vertically in the procedure output area. The DOWN= option 
is ignored unless you also use the GROUP= option.

If number-of-rows calls for more pies than fit vertically in the graphics area of the 
output device, no pies are drawn and an error message is written to the SAS log.

If you also use the ACROSS= option, the pies are drawn in left-to-right and top-to-bottom order.

[Syntax: EXPLODE=value-list] 
          
Pulls the specified slices slightly out from the rest of the pie for added emphasis. 
value-list is the list of midpoint values for the slices to be exploded.
Specifies the fill pattern for all slices in the chart.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Rotates a solid fill through the color list of the current style as many times as necessary.  SOLID is the default.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Rotates a single hatch pattern through the list of colors defined in the current style.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: FREQ=numeric-variable] 
          
Specifies a variable whose values weight the contribution of each observation in the 
computation of the chart statistic.

[Syntax: GROUP=group-variable] 
          
Organizes the data according to the values of group-variable and produces a separate 
pie(or donut) chart for each unique value of group-variable. Group-variable can be either 
character or numeric and is always treated as a discrete variable. The group variable can 
have up to 12 different values.

[Syntax: HTML=variable] 
          
Identifies the variable in the input data set whose values create links in the HTML file 
that is created by the ODS statement. These links are associated with an area of the chart 
and point to the data or graph that you want to display when the user drills down on the area.

[Syntax: HTML_LEGEND=variable] 
          
Identifies the variable in the input data set whose values create links in the HTML file 
that is created by the ODS statement. These links are associated with a legend value and 
point to the data or graph that you want to display when the user drills down on the value. 
The values of variable can be up to 1024 characters long. Characters after the 1024-character 
limit (including any closing quotes) are truncated. If either subgroups or the DETAIL= option 
are specified, then the HTML_LEGEND= option is ignored.

[Syntax: INVISIBLE=value-list] 
          
Makes the specified slices invisible, as if they had been removed from the pie. Labels 
are not printed for invisible slices. Value-list is the list of midpoint values for the 
invisible slices.

Arranges the midpoints in descending order of the statistic value and draws the slices 
clockwise starting at the twelve o'clock position.

[Syntax: LEGEND=LEGEND<1...99>] 
          
Generates a legend for the slice names (midpoint values) instead of printing them 
beside the slices.

[Syntax: LEVELS=number-of-midpoints|ALL] 
          
Specifies the number of midpoints for a numeric chart variable. The range for each midpoint 
is calculated automatically.

If you specify LEVELS=ALL, then all unique midpoint values are graphed.

The LEVELS= option is ignored if any of the following is true:

  o The chart variable is character type.
  o The MIDPOINTS= option is used.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Replace <number-of-midpoints> with the desired number of midpoints for a numeric chart variable.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that all unique midpoint values are graphed. If your data contains a large number  of unique midpoint values (over 200), you can use the XPIXELS and YPIXELS GOPTIONS to enable  the device driver to render a larger (and more readable) graph.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Uses the slice pattern color for all slice labels. MATCHCOLOR overrides the color that 
is specified in the CTEXT= option.

[Syntax: MIDPOINTS=value-list | OLD] 
          
Specifies the midpoint values for the slices. The way you specify value-list depends on the 
type of variable:
          
For numeric chart variables, value-list is either an explicit list of values, or a starting 
and an ending value with an interval increment, or a combination of both forms: 

     n <...n>
     
     n TO n <BY increment>
     
     n<...n> TO n <BY increment> <n <...n>>
 
For character chart variables, value-list is a list of unique character values enclosed in 
quotation marks and separated by blanks: 

    'value-1' <...'value-n'> 
    
MIDPOINTS=OLD generates default midpoints using the Nelder algorithm.
Generates default midpoints using the Nelder algorithm.

Accepts a missing value as a valid midpoint for the chart variable. By default, observations 
with missing values are ignored.
